comment.author: 96288512@N00
comment._content: This is an early version of the P-51. The full glass canopy wasn't until a later iteration (the P-51D). Details can be found here: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P-51_Mustang.

comment.author: 44122044@N00
comment._content: From Warbird Alley www.warbirdalley.com/p51.htm History: One of the most effective, famous and beautiful fighter aircraft of WWII, the P-51 was designed to fulfill a British requirement dated April 1940. Because of the rapidly-mounting clouds of war in Europe, the UK asked North American Aircraft to design and build a new fighter in only 120 days. The NA-73X prototype was produced in record time, but did not fly until 26 October 1940. The first RAF production models, designated Mustang Mk Is, underwent rigorous testing and evaluation, and it was found that the 1,100-hp Allison engine was well suited for low-altitude tactical reconnaissance, but the engine's power decreased dramatically above an altitude of 12,000 feet, making it a poor choice for air-to-air combat or interception roles. Because of this, the RAF left its eight machine guns intact, but also fitted the Mustang with cameras. In this configuration, it served in at least 23 RAF squadrons, beginning in April 1942. The first Merlin-engine versions appeared in 1943 with the P-51B, of which 1,988 were built in Inglewood, California, and the P-51C, of which 1,750 were built in Dallas, Texas. Both new versions had strengthened fuselages and four wing-mounted 12.7-mm machine guns. Many of these new Mustangs were delivered to the UK as Mustang Mk IIIs, and others went to the USAAF as F-6Cs. More info on the site...

comment.author: 18874793@N00
comment._content:
I'll expand on why this is a F-6A:
The production of the NA73 design for the UK had to receive the blessing of the US government before  it could become ratified. A condition of the approval was the supply of two examples to the USAAC for evaluation and these two were delivered and given the designation XP-51. Before that however the US army had already contracted for the procurement of 150 additional aircraft for supply to Britain under Lend-Lease designating these P-51 and these differed from the earlier version by having self sealing tanks and four wing mounted 20mm cannon in place of the eight machine guns. From this batch 93 were supplied to Britain, becoming designated Mustang IA, 55 went to the USAAF as F-6A's, equipped with two K-24 cameras for use in the tactical recon role and the remaining two also went to the USAAF with different engines, initially as XP-78's but later brought into the family as XP-51B's.
The designation of this aircraft in US service as P-51 came after North American opened the second plant at Dallas, Texas to increase production from the already stretched Inglewood plant which did not occur until 1943 and this image is dated October 1942. In the summer of 1943 the first  P-51B is produced at Inglewood and the identical P-51C is produced from the Dallas plant, operationally their first mission in USAAF service was on Dec 13 1943 when elements of the 8th undertook a long range escort to Keil from the UK

comment.author: 26375439@N03
comment._content: Would question the title of this photograph - the US supplied other aircraft for RAF use (or at least evaluation). Before the P-51, the Curtiss-Wright P40A-C Tomahawk was issued (not used in frontline combat), and the P40D-F Warhawk was issued under the name Kittyhawk. This website gives a comprehensive history.

comment.author: 9994874@N03
comment._content: I question the title also.  The RAF used the Douglas A-20, Catalina, even B-17s.

comment.author: 75395133@N00
comment._content:
The RAF used the North American Mustang I, IA, and II in a tactical reconnaissance role. The RAF Mustang I was armed with 4 Browning .50 calibre and 4 Browning .30 calibre machine guns. The Mustang IA was equipped with 4 Hispano MkII 20mm cannon and the Mustang II had 4 Browning .50 calibre machine guns.

The RAF Mustang III was used in a fighter role and was equipped with 4 Browning .50 calibre machine guns.

The RAF reorganised in 1943 in preparation for the opening of the second front in Europe and used the lessons learned from its operations in North Africa with the 1st Tactical Air Force - The Desert Air Force.  A 2nd Tactical Air Force was formed during the summer of 1943 and the RAF's 2 Group from Bomber Command, which encompassed all the light  twin engined daylight bombers, were all moved under the control of Fighter Command and then into the 2nd TAF.  The bomber types moved into the TAF were North American Mitchell II, and III, Douglas Boston III, IIIA, IV and V, Lockheed Ventura I, and II,and De Havilland Mosquito FBVI.  As can been seen the majority of these types of aircraft were supplied to the RAF under the lend-lease scheme with the exception of the British Mosquito.

comment.author: 37985509@N08
comment._content: If you follow the trackback to the LOC original and download it, what you find is that the negative is a 4" x 5", and thus most likely shot on a Graflex press camera of some sort (you can see the film plate holder outlines on the left and top and bottom). The LOC scanners set their resolution at 1500dpi, capturing roughly 45 megapixels of information. What's amazing about that is that at 100% magnification, you are just beginning to see the film grain. Today's press photographers, using digital equipment, can't capture even half this level of detail.

comment.author: 59814198@N06
comment._content: Looks like an early version actually designated the Apache A-36A as seen here in the US Air Force Museum in Dayton Ohio: www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=493 www.flickr.com/photos/paulgpics/6529258843/in/set-7215762... Note the top air intake used with the Allison engine. This model did not become the P-51 until it was equipped with the Packard Merlin engine which had no top air intake: www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=513
